subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Question About Jerome
msgSnippet: Jeff: In answer to your question:  Yes, Jon Zuck created Jerome.   I don t remember if he mentioned how he decided on the name Jerome. When I stumbled across
messageBody:
Jeff:

In answer to your question:  Yes, Jon Zuck created Jerome.   I don't remember if he mentioned how he decided on the name "Jerome." 

When I stumbled across the Shavian site by chance one day, almost immediately I began writing about Quikscript and asked whether anyone had ever created a QS font since I could not read Shavian fluently.  (I only used Shavian for about 3 months before Kingsley Read wrote in response to my letter and told me about QS and sent me a copy of his manual.) The response  on the Shavian site was that no one had designed a QS font as more people were aware of Shavian than of QS due to the printing of Androcles and the Lion in Shavian and Roman.

Since I knew nothing about font creation at the time, I asked if anyone would be willing to create a QS font so that those of us interested in QS could communicate on the net.  I recieved what I can only characterize as a tepid response.  One person opined they might create a QS font at some indefinite time in the future if they could get around to it.

When Jon came on the Shavian site, he became interested in QS very quickly, and set about correcting the lack of a QS font.  As you may have noticed, Jerome is not perfect, but as it was Jon's first effort at font creation, I think it is excellent under the circumstances.

There is no authority governing font creation for QS anymore than there is for the roman alphabet.  If someone wants to create another QS font, they are free to do so.  If its appearance is appealing and it works well, then it is likely that people will use it.  Anyone who is a member of Read_Alphabet can post a font for a trial if they choose to.  If a font is produced that works better than Jerome, then people would probably shift to it.

By the way, due to the conncection between Shavian and QS, Jon chose to use the Shavian keyboard mapping for Jerome.  I don't know how that mapping first came about, but in my opinion it is not easy to learn.  It might be different if one were not starting from knowledge of the roman alphabet, but I don't think there is anyone out there that is not coming from a roman background!  Therefore, (with the help of Ewout Stam pointing me to Keyman, which makes it possible) and with much assistance from Jon, I recently completed a new mapping for Jerome that, to my mind, is much easier to use in making the transition from roman to QS.  Additionally, it permits the full use of the QS half-letters  and alternative letter forms (which Shavian does not use) and the ligatures.  The actual mapping is still the old Shavian mapping, but Keyman produces what might be called an interpreter that translates your key strokes to the output needed for the actual Jerome mapping.  Keyman 3.2 is available through the Tavultesoft.com site.  The other files needed to make this work are on the Read_Alphabet site.  They are either in the font or resources section.  Try them out and I believe you will find them much easier than the Shavian mapping.  Good luck.

Sincerely,
 

Paige Gabhart

jeff_smith_8992 wrote:

 I have some (hopefully) quick questions about the Jerome font...
their real intent is to try to get a better understanding of how
stable or changeable the Jerome font is.

In looking through the past message posts to this group, it appears
that Jon Zuck completed his work on Jerome back in December of 2000.
Did he actually create Jerome? Or was he making modifications to an
already existing version of Jerome? And just out of curiosity, where
did the name "Jerome" come from?

Does anyone actually "control" the various shaw fonts, like Jerome,
Ghoti, Androcles, etc?  Is there an "official" version that you get
from some web site? Or can anyone tinker with the fonts and then
release them?

The reason I'm asking is that I've found that as I'm learning
QuickScript, I'm realizing how easy it is to take the font for
granted and assume that whenever I save a document or send a fellow
QuickScript writer an email, the font that I and others are using is
(and will be) reliable and give the expected symbol output.

Thanks,
Jeff Smith

Jeff:

In answer to your question:  Yes, Jon Zuck created Jerome.   I don't
remember if he mentioned how he decided on the name "Jerome."

When I stumbled across the Shavian site by chance one day, almost
immediately I began writing about Quikscript and asked whether anyone
had ever created a QS font since I could not read Shavian fluently.  (I
only used Shavian for about 3 months before Kingsley Read wrote in
response to my letter and told me about QS and sent me a copy of his
manual.) The response  on the Shavian site was that no one had designed
a QS font as more people were aware of Shavian than of QS due to the
printing of Androcles and the Lion in Shavian and Roman.

Since I knew nothing about font creation at the time, I asked if anyone
would be willing to create a QS font so that those of us interested in
QS could communicate on the net.  I recieved what I can only
characterize as a tepid response.  One person opined they might create a
QS font at some indefinite time in the future if they could get around
to it.

When Jon came on the Shavian site, he became interested in QS very
quickly, and set about correcting the lack of a QS font.  As you may
have noticed, Jerome is not perfect, but as it was Jon's first effort at
font creation, I think it is excellent under the circumstances.

There is no authority governing font creation for QS anymore than there
is for the roman alphabet.  If someone wants to create another QS font,
they are free to do so.  If its appearance is appealing and it works
well, then it is likely that people will use it.  Anyone who is a member
of Read_Alphabet can post a font for a trial if they choose to.  If a
font is produced that works better than Jerome, then people would
probably shift to it.

By the way, due to the conncection between Shavian and QS, Jon chose to
use the Shavian keyboard mapping for Jerome.  I don't know how that
mapping first came about, but in my opinion it is not easy to learn.  It
might be different if one were not starting from knowledge of the roman
alphabet, but I don't think there is anyone out there that is not coming
from a roman background!  Therefore, (with the help of Ewout Stam
pointing me to Keyman, which makes it possible) and with much assistance
from Jon, I recently completed a new mapping for Jerome that, to my
mind, is much easier to use in making the transition from roman to QS.
Additionally, it permits the full use of the QS half-letters  and
alternative letter forms (which Shavian does not use) and the
ligatures.  The actual mapping is still the old Shavian mapping, but
Keyman produces what might be called an interpreter that translates your
key strokes to the output needed for the actual Jerome mapping.  Keyman
3.2 is available through the Tavultesoft.com site.  The other files
needed to make this work are on the Read_Alphabet site.  They are either
in the font or resources section.  Try them out and I believe you will
find them much easier than the Shavian mapping.  Good luck.

Sincerely,


Paige Gabhart

Jeff:
<p>In answer to your question:  Yes, Jon Zuck created Jerome.  
I don't remember if he mentioned how he decided on the name "Jerome." 
<p>When I stumbled across the Shavian site by chance one day, almost immediately
I began writing about Quikscript and asked whether anyone had ever created
a QS font since I could not read Shavian fluently.  (I only used Shavian
for about 3 months before Kingsley Read wrote in response to my letter
and told me about QS and sent me a copy of his manual.) The response 
on the Shavian site was that no one had designed a QS font as more people
were aware of Shavian than of QS due to the printing of Androcles and the
Lion in Shavian and Roman.
<p>Since I knew nothing about font creation at the time, I asked if anyone
would be willing to create a QS font so that those of us interested in
QS could communicate on the net.  I recieved what I can only characterize
as a tepid response.  One person opined they might create a QS font
at some indefinite time in the future if they could get around to it.
<p>When Jon came on the Shavian site, he became interested in QS very quickly,
and set about correcting the lack of a QS font.  As you may have noticed,
Jerome is not perfect, but as it was Jon's first effort at font creation,
I think it is excellent under the circumstances.
<p>There is no authority governing font creation for QS anymore than there
is for the roman alphabet.  If someone wants to create another QS
font, they are free to do so.  If its appearance is appealing and
it works well, then it is likely that people will use it.  Anyone
who is a member of Read_Alphabet can post a font for a trial if they choose
to.  If a font is produced that works better than Jerome, then people
would probably shift to it.
<p>By the way, due to the conncection between Shavian and QS, Jon chose
to use the Shavian keyboard mapping for Jerome.  I don't know how
that mapping first came about, but in my opinion it is not easy to learn. 
It might be different if one were not starting from knowledge of the roman
alphabet, but I don't think there is anyone out there that is not coming
from a roman background!  Therefore, (with the help of Ewout Stam
pointing me to Keyman, which makes it possible) and with much assistance
from Jon, I recently completed a new mapping for Jerome that, to my mind,
is much easier to use in making the transition from roman to QS. 
Additionally, it permits the full use of the QS half-letters  and
alternative letter forms (which Shavian does not use) and the ligatures. 
The actual mapping is still the old Shavian mapping, but Keyman produces
what might be called an interpreter that translates your key strokes to

through the Tavultesoft.com site.  The other files needed to make
this work are on the Read_Alphabet site.  They are either in the font
or resources section.  Try them out and I believe you will find them
much easier than the Shavian mapping.  Good luck.
<p>Sincerely,
<br> 
<p>Paige Gabhart
